div.p: It started up from when I was at school, I was in my final year I’d done my GCSEs, left school to get a summer job and went to work
for a company that did this sort of work and found I really enjoyed it and it was nice I wasn’t at school any more and I was meant to
go back and do my A-Levels and I never went back and I just followed that line... I suppose it was an escape from school in a way
which although I was quite good at I didn’t really like, I went through a period of wanting to join the RAF but for some reason
I didn’t go down that line so yes I found it interesting and so I followed that line and then went, took some guidance to go to college
and get my training as it wasn’t just going into a job without any training and went from there really and progressed from an apprentice
up to moving up the ladder to finally actually the company we worked for my father worked for as well and it went into liquidation
well they closed down they’d had enough of that particular business and we took it on from then. I suppose I enjoyed that it wasn’t
the same thing every day it wasn’t a repetition and I enjoyed the problem solving aspect of it and ways to get around a problem
that I’ve thought of myself rather than a set pattern of things to follow i.e. if you’re working on a production line or something
you just picked product A, B and C I mean it was always a problem solving type of job and also the interaction with lots of different people.
